content:
When Lemmas 7.7.2 and 7.7.3 are applied in the first part of the proof of Proposition 2.0.4, they need the assumption that ‖(rowSupport t j).indicator g x‖ ≤ G.indicator 1 x for all j < 2 ^ n. But g is only BoundedCompactSupport, not less than a pure indicator function; furthermore rowSupport is defined as the union of several E p, but E does not depend on G at all, so I cannot conclude that ‖(rowSupport t j).indicator g x‖ ≤ G.indicator 1 x.

I suspect there are several omissions here. Was E₁ or E₂ meant instead of E in defining rowSupport?
See L617, L620 and L621 in Forests.lean in fpvandoorn/carleson#379 for where the less-than-indicator assumptions are needed

Oh, that seems like a small mistake. Proposition 2.0.4 is only applied for the case that g=1G∖G′g = 1_{G\setminus G'}g=1G∖G′​, so the easiest fix is to add the assumption g≤1Gg\le 1_Gg≤1G​ to the Proposition. In the formalisation, this means you have to add the assumption A⊆GA\subseteq GA⊆G to forest_operator' and forest_operator_le_volume.
Lars says that another fix is to indeed replace EEE by E1E_1E1​ in the definition of EjE_jEj​. That also works, and doesn't require changing Proposition 2.0.4 (but I'm fine with either option).
The first half of Prop 2.0.4 (g part) is done; I used the A⊆GA \subseteq GA⊆G fix
Now I run into another logical gap in the second part (the one with the dens_2). How do I go from 1Ej\mathbf 1_{E_j}1Ej​​ to 1F\mathbf 1_F1F​ so that I can apply Equation (7.7.2) of Lemma 7.7.2?
(The notation in row-bound seems to be off as well; I have tried to correct them in my PR, both blueprint and code)
fpvandoorn/carleson#379 has been updated with my current progress; I'm stuck on the above blueprint error
@Floris van Doorn I've completed the Prop 2.0.4 proof except the second logical gap I pointed out above (1Ej\mathbf 1_{E_j}1Ej​​ to 1F\mathbf 1_F1F​)

There are indeed some steps missing in the proof. The main thing to note is that Lemma 7.2.2 is about T∗T^*T∗, while in this proof we need a bound for TTT (I'm omitting the subscripts in this post).
We know that TTT and T∗T^*T∗ are adjoint: ⟨Tf,g⟩=⟨f,T∗g⟩\langle Tf, g\rangle = \langle f, T^*g\rangle⟨Tf,g⟩=⟨f,T∗g⟩, this is (roughly?): carleson#TileStructure.Forest.adjointCarlesonSum_adjoint
From that, it is not hard to show that T1FT1_{F}T1F​ is adjoint to 1FT∗1_{F}T^*1F​T∗ (note the swap of the indicator functions). Then, from Equation 7.7.2 we get for fff with ∣f∣≤1F|f|\le1_F∣f∣≤1F​ that

∥1GTf∥22=⟨1GTf,1GTf⟩=⟨Tf,1GTf⟩=⟨f,T∗1GTf⟩=⟨1Ff,T∗1GTf⟩=⟨f,1FT∗1GTf⟩≤∥f∥2∥1FT∗1GTf∥2≤C∥f∥2∥1GTf∥2≤C∥f∥2∥Tf∥2\|1_GTf\|_2^2=\langle 1_GTf, 1_GTf\rangle = \langle Tf, 1_GTf\rangle = \langle f, T^*1_GTf\rangle\\ = \langle 1_Ff, T^*1_GTf\rangle = \langle f, 1_FT^*1_GTf\rangle\\ \le \|f\|_2 \|1_FT^*1_GTf\|_2\\ \le C \|f\|_2 \|1_GTf\|_2 \le C \|f\|_2 \|Tf\|_2∥1G​Tf∥22​=⟨1G​Tf,1G​Tf⟩=⟨Tf,1G​Tf⟩=⟨f,T∗1G​Tf⟩=⟨1F​f,T∗1G​Tf⟩=⟨f,1F​T∗1G​Tf⟩≤∥f∥2​∥1F​T∗1G​Tf∥2​≤C∥f∥2​∥1G​Tf∥2​≤C∥f∥2​∥Tf∥2​

Here the first inequality is Cauchy-Schwarz and the second equality is 7.7.2 (TfTfTf and hence 1GTf1_GTf1G​Tf is bounded with compact support, and its support is a subset of GGG).
Now ∥Tf∥2<∞\|Tf\|_2<\infty∥Tf∥2​<∞, so we can cancel it from both sides of the inequality to get ∥1GTf∥≤C∗∥f∥2\|1_GTf\|\le C * \|f\|_2∥1G​Tf∥≤C∗∥f∥2​.
I'll still think about how to ensure that TfTfTf (or something similar) has support in GGG.

To get our support in GGG, we use our newly added hypothesis that ∣g∣≤1G|g|\le 1_G∣g∣≤1G​, so we can multiply all functions in (7.7.7) by 1G1_G1G​. We can still prove the proposition from the inequalities with 1G1_G1G​ added. I'll edit the calculation above to insert 1G1_G1G​.

I believe you can estimate ∥1EjTRjf∥≤∥TRjf∥\|1_{E_j}T_{R_j}f\|\le \|T_{R_j}f\|∥1Ej​​TRj​​f∥≤∥TRj​​f∥ before applying the argument I described above; I don't think they play a role anymore in this part of the argument (unless I'm missing something).
All this talk about adjoints and indicators and operators, without mentioning integrals, is making my head spin
There's just one little thing left: how can I be sure that ∣1GTf∣≤1G|\mathbf 1_GTf|\le\mathbf 1_G∣1G​Tf∣≤1G​ (as that is an assumption of Lemma 7.7.2)?

Jeremy Tan said:

There's just one little thing left: how can I be sure that ∣1GTf∣≤1G|\mathbf 1_GTf|\le\mathbf 1_G∣1G​Tf∣≤1G​ (as that is an assumption of Lemma 7.7.2)?

I'm afraid that is only true up to a constant. Tf is bounded with compact support, so for a large enough c, ∣1c1GTf∣≤1G|\frac1c1_GTf|\le1_G∣c1​1G​Tf∣≤1G​. With the refactor of BoundedCompactSupport, you'll have to mimic carleson#MeasureTheory.BoundedCompactSupport.bddAbove_norm_adjointCarleson to get a uniform bound instead of an a.e.-bound (though the proof will be essentially the same as the first field of carleson#MeasureTheory.BoundedCompactSupport.carlesonOn
